Haven't played this game in half a year, but I have to speak up lest some poor sap get suckered in during the sale.  Chivalry was incredibly fun two years ago before all the exploits in the system were discovered, but they quickly became the metagame once they were mastered. Instantaneous overheads, feinting at no stamina cost, the ridiculous range of mouse dragging, all of this contributed to the game in its current (read: current as of half a year ago when I last gave it a chance) state. If running around in circles making noncommittal dives at someone until finally making a timid landing while moving erratically with your mouse is an experience you feel is worth five dollars, go for it. But be sure to avoid sticky papers and bright lights leading to zappers, because you're probably a house fly if that appeals to you.

This game has a really solid game engine and great performance in the original maps (terrible in the new maps). The feel of melee combat is awesome, with great sounds and fantastic animations. It looks great and plays great.  The reason I don't recommend this is that when you get to a high enough skill level, the gameplay drops to a level of absurdity that involves confusing the game engine by contorting your character's body in all sorts of ways that are impossible in real life, to cause the side of your weapon's hitbox to collide with back of the enemy's exposed hitbox. I.e. turning your character 180 degrees while cutting straight down (or stabbing forward) with a very long two handed weapon, trying to make the flat of the blade (not the edge or tip) touch your opponent's back at the last second of the swing. Your character being off-balance and stumbling forward gives you a great range advantage when you can spin on your heels with the mouse to guide the already finished strike (but still active hitbox) into your enemy. This is just one of the styles to guide a vertical strike of any kind for a hit, and there are many other awkward and unnatural ways to make contact and kite with different weapons at top level play.  I'd recommend this game for casuals since its fun when its casual vs casual, but then those casuals end up having to face the pros on the same server and don't have a prayer because of the abnormal weapon styles.  The devs missed the mark with this one by a small margin, and hopefully a sequel to this game might be able to improve on some of the failures from the ground up with new code.

After playing this game over the past couple of years on and off, I decided to write a review. The premise of this game is great, two factions fighting eachother with numerous different game modes, different classes with their specific jobs, and even a new co-op mode for those who don't like playing player vs player. However, I don't recommend this game to anyone currently and to look for another one. The reasons are the game mechanics. It's not realistic at all and it breaks the immersion. For example, a vanguard would be fighting three different people, instead of taking a defensive position they'd just walk backwards and forwards swinging their Zweihander like they are blind infinitely. There's also the weird mechanic of looking directly at the ground while overheading to get a super fast overhead that is most of the time impossible to block. And there's the mechanic known as 'matrixing' where you would crouch down and look at the sky, manipulating your player model so that the other person can't hit you even though they are right in front of you. I really wanted to like this game but it isn't for me, maybe I'd come back to it just to finish the achievements or when they bring updates to the mechanics.

I feel compelled to wright a review of this because this SHOULD be a good game.  The concept and play style of this game are great. The objective matches are fun, ffa is a blast, and team deathmatch is excellent. However you will quickly get over the fun of cleaving heads and arms from bodies when you try to improve your skills. Thats where things get frustrating.  There is some skill required to time your stikes and parrys correctly and that is an excellent dynamic, however, it all really comes down to your ping, and your enemies ping in the end. You will freqiently see your arrows pass through others, blows that land, but dont, and you'll be beheaded by enemies that are not even swinging their weapons. The differences between how you perceive your moves and how the sprites perform are sluggish as best. This makes the combat clunky and hard to use, and you find quickly that there are a few weapons and classes that make buttonmashing an easy way to accidentally kill others.  Don't buy this game, maybe someday, some studio will make a great melee battle game but it pains me to say this isn't it. you'll have a few hours of fun maybe but then your left wanting more and wondering why this isn't early access or alpha build.

SO. To try and organize the pros/cons with the game.. hmm... Well, to start off I suppose I could just say that its frustrating and aggravating.  First and foremost, the first thing you'll notice is that the community in this game complains. A lot. Every game you join, every class will complain that one of the other classes is OP. Gets annoying, but hey, I guess the devs know this, so there's a chat disable option in the config when you press Escape.  Second: BALANCE. Specifically, shields. They are SO easy to use. They make you immune to feints, archers, and generally any attacks as long as there's less than, say, 3 people attacking you at any given time. Being double or triple teamed? No problem; you have a shield. You can just turtle until help comes around. Archers killing your whole team? No fear; you have a shield. None else can block arrows but you. Going up a good player who attacks unpredictably? No fear; you have a shield and can just hold it up until he runs out of stamina. As long as you can keep up with where the attacks are coming from, you can always beat someone without a shield. The rest of the game is debatable, what with the different class abilities (knights have HP, Men At Arms have.. SOME speed, Vanguards have one shot charge attacks, and archers just sorta hang off in the background safe and sound), but shields really do get annoying. But hey, you can use one too. Unless you're a vanguard, they you'll just have to settle for having the best weapons in the game.  Third: Fun: Is the game fun? Can be if you go up against someone who's pretty much as good (or bad) as you. Other than that, you'll probably die instantly from what's left of the playerbase, which is just people who have 700 hours each of gametime. Fun to play with friends, if you can convince them to buy a game on the few hours you'll play it. Most players seem to quit this game before they get to level 17. Most of the players you'll see are about level 40-50 (pretty dang high). The vast majority of servers on the list are always empty. You'll have to settle for playing Free For All most of the time, which means lots of vanguards running around nearly one shotting you from behind, unless you're a knight, in which case you'll still die a lot in FFA. Vanguards reign supreme there.  Oh yeah, there's Low Level servers now for levels 0-15 for you to learn the ropes on. Once you hit level 16, time to go into the big boy servers and fight people who know all the game's mechanics, flaws, and exploits. Review:   Chivalry Mediavel Warfare is a very competitive, skill-based game with a medieval atmosphere. The combat are realistic and fast-paced. With 4 classes and over 60 weapons, you're almost sure to find a build that suits your fighting style. The game is based on skill and practice. You unlock weapon by using other weapons of the same category. The only things you can unlock with money is cosmetic, so it's not a Pay-To-Win. It has 5 interesting gamemodes and custom maps and mods.   Pro:  -Based on skill and practice. You can not pay to have upgrades you must practice to get better. -Dragging, Matrixing and other such things are very fun to learn and use in fights, even if they bugs. -Very fun, once you know how to fight. -Lots of different builds possible. -Team Objective, Team Deathmatch, Last Team Standing and Duel are fun and very easy to get better. -Nice graphics.   Con:  -Lots of hackers and team-killers on beginner servers- unintentional for the latter. And when you accuse someone of hacking, other people say you're a newbie and you don't know the game. -Lots of intentional team-killers on normal servers. -There is a huge difference of skills between beginner servers and normal servers. -The community can be very toxic with its hackers, team-killers, ragers and other such people. -If you've got a high ping or more than 10-15% team damage, you're gonna get kick. -It's very long and hard to be good. It took me 10 hours to be half-way decent on beginner servers. It takes hundred of hours to be good on normal server. And all the while you're gonna get destroy by better people and end the game with 2/23/4. -The devs have stopped working on the games. That means all the little annoying bugs aren't going to get fixed. On the other side, positive bugs suchs as dragging aren't gonna get removed either.   Beginner tips:  -First thing you should do after buying the game is the Training Map. Go in Training then Training Map. It shows you have to block, attack, combo, feint and how to play the different classes. It's very useful at the beginning. -Use a shield. Don't hold it in position all the time but use it to block more easily until you get used to the speed of the weapons and dragging. -If you're playing as a Vanguard or a Knight, don't side-swing in team games. You're gonna end up killing more allies than ennemies and get kick. -If you like to do a lot of burst damage and have a good defense, pick Knight. If you like to do a lot of damage and keep your distance use Vanguard. If you like to attack very fast use Man-At-Arm. -Don't play Archer until you're used to blocking with a sword. Archer is the hardest class to master. -Stick to beginner servers until you're level 10 to 15. But don't wait until you're 16 to play on normal server or it'll be twice as hard.

Pros:  + Quick and fun to play  Cons:  - Awkward damage modeling; slow strikes do as much damage as fast ones, and bending matrix-style to swing a polearm can hit someone behind you (when physically it should not be even possible to do this). The end and start of weapon swings do full damage, even though physically this should result in minimal damage due to low momentum. - Rough around the edges; approaching a ramp from the side can cause you to get stuck in the air. Many other bugs present in the game. - Awkward hit registration. Strikes that LOOK like they should connect do not connect. Strikes from the side sometimes connect with a shield even when there is nothing in the way.   Verdict: 4/10. It's quick, bloody and fun. But if you are looking for a realistic medieval combat simulation, this is not your game. It's also littered with janky animations and weird bugs all around. And once you have left the noob servers, be prepared for the onslaught of veteran players who know how to abuse 'dragging' (delaying or speeding up swings to catch you off-guard) to ridiculous levels, as well as those who know how to abuse the terrible animations to contort their character's body to dodge weapons in physically impossible ways. Infinitely frustrating when there are these players in the game; and in all honesty, if a game is frustrating to no end because of its broken mechanics which people abuse, then there is probably little point to playing it for fun. Because unless you have some masochistic tendencies, and you enjoy dying a million times over to bug abusers, then you will not find this game fun. YMMV.

Where do I start with this one?  Ok, so this game is a very basic medieval combat simulator. Swing your sword, shoot your bow, throw your axe or fire your catapult and grotesquely dismember your foes among castles and vallies of a time long pass! Or, just ragequit after high levels of frustration.  So what's fun about this game? The use of medieval weapons like swords and shields, the arena style gameplay, and dismemberment physics that are gore and blood done right!  The bad? Pretty much everything else. I managed to do pretty well in a short amount of time, climbing the scoreboards and getting over the noob hump relatively quick. Unfortunately in my group of friends, I was the only one. Everyone I was playing with could not get used to glitch exploitation and angry MW players that are more obtuse than that little troll the billy goat had to stomp da' ♥♥♥♥ out. The game also disconnected a fair amount and had a lot of lag issues.  Overall the gaming experience is skin deep and the gameplay feels like a mod, not an officially released game. I know, I know, this game was originally a mod. But that's no excuse for this game being so glitchy and unpolished, especially since they seem to release DLC for an otherwise messy game.  If you want to bang your head against a wall for a few hours, buy this game for 2.50 during a steam sale. But if you want rich combat and immersive gameplay with a decent community to back it, then abandon all your hope, ye who enter here.

I really enjoy the idea of this game, and when it works, I have a blast. But because of the spotty hit detection. I'm left wishing I had saved my money.  July 2015: A year Later nothing has changed... It has only gotten worse. US servers are bombarded by people across the globe with pings in the 300's taking advantage of the garbage hit detection. Try to take advantage of this yourself and join a server half way across the world, and you're instantly kicked. Aparrently we're just too kind and allow anyone to walk into our servers... Interesting.  Besides the game breaking Client side hit detection, the game has become nothing more than a metagame of even more ridiculous exploits that have never been fixed by the devs. Why? (Wow, I hit the character limit for reviews. I didn't know that was a thing.)   Note: My focus of this review will be on the Archer class. I understand that the melee combat is the selling point of this game, and I will touch on it. But I often see tons of people talk about what is wrong with the melee system, and I feel like the issues surrounding the Archer don't get acknowledged as much as they should.    (Also note that this review will be VERY lengthy; I doubt that very many people will see it, but I want to make sure that the few that do know the state that Chivalry is in. But another big reason that I'm writing this is the fact that I loved this game, and hate to see what has happened to it. This is why my review is rather biased.)      Chivalry: Medieval Warfare has suffered a problem that contrasts the stereotypical 'indie game': A fair bit of the stuff you find from indie companies tends to be a half-a**ed alpha/beta version that runs terribly and is in dire need of improvement. (At least, this is one of many images that the term 'indie' has received.) And in the majority of those cases, the game is later abandoned by the developer(s), and left to rot; it never becomes a better game. Well, Chivalry has run this course backwards: What started out as a flawed, but overall well-executed game has become a pile of glitches and 'features' that has chased away several long-term players, myself being one.      --- Summary (of how the gameplay functions, that is) ---    So let's go over the basics of gameplay. There are four classes: Knight, Vanguard, Man-At-Arms, and Archer. The Knight is a tank class that wields many strong two-handed weapons, along with a secondary one-handed weapon and shield. The Vanguard is an assault class that, while having less protection than the Knight, utilizes a number of heavy swords, spears, and halberds. The Vanguard is capable of charging: After sprinting around for a period of time, he will place his arms in a locked-position of sorts. This indicates that, when you left-click, he will lunge forward and strike the enemy, dealing a massive blow that can even one-shot some classes. The third class, the Man-At-Arms, is agile. He can 'dodge' out of the way of attacks by means of either double-tapping a directional button, or a 'One-button dodge' shortcut, configurable in the Settings. With swords and maces, this class is about running in, avoiding attacks, and landing moderate, fast damage to enemies. This would be the last melee class recommended to new players, due to its low health and dodging mechanics that can be somewhat difficult to understand. Finally, the Archer is the black sheep: His primary weapon consists of either a bow, a crossbow, or javelins. Depending on which you choose, you'll either be in the back firing arrows at enemy classes to weaken/kill them, taking out enemy Archers to help your teammates, or charge into melee range and act as both a fighter as well as a distraction. This class has the lowest health of all, and should avoid melee combat as often as possible.    All attacks cost energy, which is depleted from a bar that appears on-screen with the health bar. Swinging without hitting somebody (and with it, feinting), parrying/blocking, holding a loaded arrow on the bow, and kicking use up some of this energy. And when that bar runs out, you can no longer do combo attacks, and if you parry/block an attack, you get stunned for a little while, which gives the enemy the chance you attack you while you're unable to defend yourself. You have to wait until it recharges before heading back into combat.    The way that maps work on servers is very similar to other PvP games: You have your standard Capture the Flag, King of the Hill, Free-for-All, Team Deathmatch, etc.. I won't go over how each of them works, because I assume that you'll either already know, or are willing to take a couple minutes to look them up. In addition to these, you also have two gamemodes that aren't seen quite as often: Duel, in which a group of people are put up against eachother in a 1 v.s 1 style, and the person with the most amount of victories at the end is declared the winner. And the second, Team Objective: In this mode, players are placed on two teams of either 12 or 16, where one is playing offense, and the other, defense. One of the teams has a set of goals that they must accomplish in a set period of time, before they end up losing the match. The other team's objective is to stop them from achieving those goals. If offense wins, then the two move on to the next objective. These objectives can range from things such as pushing a wagon through a gate, shooting down a barricade with a Ballista, slaying peasants, and even killing one of the two military generals that commands the teams: Feydrid Kearn, and Malric Terrowin.    The game supports player-owned servers, as well as modding. But to raise your rank (which is, for the most part, simply just a number), you have to play on the official Torn Banner-hosted servers. Your 'rank' allows you to unlock special helmets at different levels: At 30, you get a silver version of the default helmets. At 40, a Black version of the Veteran helmets, a gold at 50, and a pink at 60, etc.. You can also gain access to veteran helmets by unlocking all the primary weapons of a class, which involves getting a specific number of kills using any of the weapons in a section of the weapons list.      --- The Issues ---    So, what are the problems with this game? Well, as I mentioned at the start, this is a game that has gone sour the more it gets updated. At the start, people were presented with a game that uses a combat system that relied on timing, accuracy, focus, and didn't have the sort of 'whoever attacks first, wins' feeling that arises from other PvP games, namely first-person shooters. People appeared to have clung to that idea, and as a result, made Chivalry quite a popular game. At one point (in 2013, if I'm not mistaken), they had sold over 1.2 million copies of the game, which is rather impressive for a first standalone game (as it originally started out as a Half-Life 2 mod by the name of 'Age of Chivalry'). Over time, though, that good combat system has deteriorated, to the point that people have left the game entirely.    To make a long story short: Certain melee weapons in the game have been unbalanced for a very long time (some from the very start, from what I've been told by friends), and continue to be unbalanced to this day, 3-4 years later. Torn Banner has adopted the idea of 'it's not a bug, it's a feature' when it comes to the fighting styles that you see. For example, if you turn your player to have their back face the enemy, crouch, point your camera straight up to the sky, and perform an overhead, the weapon will strike the enemy and deal damage to them during the 'wind-up phase'. (This is supposed to be the point where your character is readying their weapon for a strike, and gives players a short window of time to counter-strike, before they have to block or dodge out of the way.) And if your weapon is slow enough, such as the Maul for the Knight, then you can turn your character around after the 'reverse-overhead' attack lands, and hit your opponent twice, which will kill anybody, assuming they don't block either one or both of the attacks. Another combat style, which is used heavily now-a-days, is known as 'dragging'. This is a very basic concept: If you swing your weapon to the left, then you turn right during the attack to 'drag' your weapon, thus slowing the swing speed and causing your opponent to (hopefully) block too early. Summary: Pass, unless you want to end up featured in one of those 'gamers rage' YouTube compilation videos.  Chivalry: Medieval Warfare is the single most frustrating game that I have ever played.  The premise and execution looked intriguing enough initially; however, once I dove into the game itself I found that this game really punishes you for dying. Not only are you brutally mangled by other players, but the camera forces you to watch your body ragdoll for quite a while before it allows you to look away to 'ghost' after other players, while simultaneously showing you just how many times that other player has killed you. It feels like everything about the death system is about rubbing your nose in it. Unless you're on a kill streak and you're just on fire (proverbially), it's a really unpleasant and enfuriating experience. The Free-For-All gameplay mode is a joke. A surprisingly large number of players rage about 'honor' and fighting one-on-one in some of the team-based play modes, but once it becomes a free-for-all, 'honor' goes out the window and everyone is running around looking for opportunities to stab- or shoot- someone else in the back.  If I did well in the game, it felt dull, like there was no challenge. If I did poorly, it was infuriating and I felt challenged to continue to play until I was able to do better. Whether I did poorly or well, every time I stopped playing the game, I considered just uninstalling it.  Chivalry: Medieval Warfare is one of the prettiest and most promising failures I've played in some time, but ultimately it is - in my opinion - a complete and utter failure. I never once had a moment in this game where I thought 'wow, that was really fun.' When I won, I was bored, and when I lost, I was infuriated. I've never experienced that before in a game, and it was a such a bad experience that I'm never going back.

TL;DR: if you want to get this game AND be decent at it, you're going to want to devote, many many hours into it, and at the end it's all pointless.

I was at first excited to play this game, I had seen videos on youtube and thought it would be fun. Well, its not. Overall: 2/10  Pros first (short list): -Fair Graphics for no visual lag. -Fairly easy controls for all that you can do. -Tons of servers to play on.  Cons (long list): -The games physics as relates to bows is a joke, base-line bows of the time had much better distance and travel time on arrows. -Lengths of weapons are not properly simulated, Classes with the heaviest armor seem to be the weakest (Note on history: anyone in that time period who wore that level of armor was raised to be a soldier from a really young age, they could realitively easily scale walls in full body armor and their weapons, this game fails to simulate that.) -Mapping as for running and slashing is fine, but the Archer class is highly ignored in the designs with a massive lack of elevated areas to shoot from, as was the case in history in defence situations with Archers using walls, towers and rooftops. -Armor ranking seems to mean next to nothing between the classes. -While friendly damage is expected, the penalties for it I found rather stupid given archers always end up hitting friendlies (been on both ends of the bow.) -Team killing/wounding is a common and idiotic happening in this game and commonly makes for failed team matches. Specially when 80% of your teams on FFA right outside the spawn.  There is a much longer list of things I found that makes this game undesirable to play, but I dont feel like its worth the time writing that much out.   In short: If you know anything about history and/or have held/used the real weapons, dont play this game. If you just love seeing tons of gore and blood and dont really care at all about a game being based on a historical time period being inaccurate as heck, then I would suggest this is a game for you.

I'll start by saying, I love this ♥♥♥♥ing game. I can't stop playing it, however, I do equate it to flogging myself; against unrealistic/broken physics and metagamer movement exploits of these failures.   I don't recommend people buy it until a few key issues are addressed.   Level 1-16 are a whirlwhind of fun for non-meta gamers. After you reach a certain level (takes 1-3 days), you are cast into a 'non-noob' rank pool of players. As a competent gamer, I was completely stunned by the immediate brick wall you face when you 'graduate' post lv 16. There needs to be a game-mode which enforces a HALO-style rank/matchmaking system so that players can be matched together based on an average recent skill.   I've noticed there are two types of players in Chivalry: Those who play and move their character based on their perception of real life physics [and] Those who exploit the game engine's weak grasp on realistic physics. Some gamers prefer to win at all costs; even if its sprinting, jumping crouching and swinging 100 pound claymore from left shoulder to right shoulder as if it were a twig, all at the same time. To make the physics worse, the devs have decided to add a speed factor to swinging a weapon based on how fast the player can move the mouse. What you'll find is players with LOW DPI mice, huge mouse pads, spamming tons of keys, jumping, crouching, looking down and swiping their mice wildly across a huge mouse pad. The client [you, the player] cant even properly render the movement-spam these players are producing, while you're dying to a sword you didn't even see swing. It makes any logical/reaction-based sword strategy extremely difficult to execute. The developers need to implement better physics based on the gear the different classes use. Weight factor should be reduced if a player opts to carry less weapons or equipment. Remove the ridiculous fast-mouse-power-swing idea. Slow player movement down or show me videos where people can wear full body-chain mail, have a tower shield on their back, jump 5 feet in the air while crouching into a cannonball and managing to swing and hit with a claymore before they hit the ground. This isn't Call of Duty guy-.. wait..   If player 'effectiveness' were ranked, there wouldn't be lopsided servers in almost every occasion.  It takes me 10-30 minutes before this game becomes unbearable..  Yet I keep going back.

Coming from an Age of Chivalry background, long time player, I've recently decided to purchase both the original and the expansion. The time I've spent on this game, it was an awkward trade of fun and frustration, the only fun I had was when I wielded a 2 handed spear, how it provided me with enough distance to poke enemies to death easily, yet what I really looked forward in this game was being an archer, or for the expansion, being a pirate.   If you purchase this game, don't bother much with range weapons, either you're good enough to hit a human with an ant-size bullet/arrow, or be killed easily by a spear and shield Spartan, given the reason that range classes have poor melee weapons, pirates have a default short sword which is not going to save you from a 2 handed sword landing a building breaking smash over your defenseless head. Not only I find it rather annoying and difficult to land a shot, but reloading takes all of your patience, especially crossbow, the character would bend over, spending about 3 seconds to reload and when the character gets up, you only see the tip of a spear ramming down your eye, nonetheless whether you score the shot or not, it only takes about a few percent of life, you still need to draw your safety-precaution approved sword and land a few hits.    I feel the game is unbalanced, for that reason, you barely see range weapons, just Spartans, Knights, Vikings, and some Samurai around. Because people like to win easily, they would rather sprint towards you, slice you in half before you even get a chance to respond, given the fact that it takes time to swap weapons and mispressing would lead to swapping back to another weapon, not to mention if you are reloading and get hit, your weapon remains unloaded. My biggest complaint is with range classes, they are plain hard to use, forcing most people to for the easy win classes. I wouldn't recommend this game if you like pirates, playing as one, or unbalanced games.

I'll start by saying, I love this ♥♥♥♥ing game. I can't stop playing it, however, I do equate it to flogging myself; against unrealistic/broken physics and metagamer movement exploits of these failures.   I don't recommend people buy it until a few key issues are addressed.   Level 1-16 are a whirlwhind of fun for non-meta gamers. After you reach a certain level (takes 1-3 days), you are cast into a 'non-noob' rank pool of players. As a competent gamer, I was completely stunned by the immediate brick wall you face when you 'graduate' post lv 16. There needs to be a game-mode which enforces a HALO-style rank/matchmaking system so that players can be matched together based on an average recent skill.   I've noticed there are two types of players in Chivalry: Those who play and move their character based on their perception of real life physics [and] Those who exploit the game engine's weak grasp on realistic physics. Some gamers prefer to win at all costs; even if its sprinting, jumping crouching and swinging 100 pound claymore from left shoulder to right shoulder as if it were a twig, all at the same time. To make the physics worse, the devs have decided to add a speed factor to swinging a weapon based on how fast the player can move the mouse. What you'll find is players with LOW DPI mice, huge mouse pads, spamming tons of keys, jumping, crouching, looking down and swiping their mice wildly across a huge mouse pad. The client [you, the player] cant even properly render the movement-spam these players are producing, while you're dying to a sword you didn't even see swing. It makes any logical/reaction-based sword strategy extremely difficult to execute. The developers need to implement better physics based on the gear the different classes use. Weight factor should be reduced if a player opts to carry less weapons or equipment. Remove the ridiculous fast-mouse-power-swing idea. Slow player movement down or show me videos where people can wear full body-chain mail, have a tower shield on their back, jump 5 feet in the air while crouching into a cannonball and managing to swing and hit with a claymore before they hit the ground. This isn't Call of Duty guy-.. wait..   If player 'effectiveness' were ranked, there wouldn't be lopsided servers in almost every occasion.  It takes me 10-30 minutes before this game becomes unbearable..  Yet I keep going back.
